text: In this short video, we'll be discussing
noun clauses with if and whether.
So noun clauses with if or whether are
just like uh any other noun clause.
They're dependent clauses. So they need
to be attached to an independent clause.
And we use if or whether to introduce
these types of noun clauses.
Um, we use these types of noun clauses
to change yes or no questions into noun
clauses or dependent clauses.
We use statement word order in these
types of noun clauses. Just like the wh
question noun clauses,
we don't use question word order
and we don't use a question mark at the
end of the uh sentence if the noun
clause is in a statement.
So let's look at some examples.
We have this first yes or no question.
Are the students studying? Now, we want
to try to change this into a noun
clause. So, we start with the
independent clause. The instructor wants
to know. Just made this independent
clause up. And we're going to add if.
And then we switch the subject and verb
so that they're in statement word order.
So, we have the instructor wants to know
if the students are studying.
Here's another example. Did the students
see the email?
Start with a independent clause. She
wonders. Then we can use if or whether
and then use statement word form
afterwards. She wonders if the students
saw the email. So you can see that in
the original question we have the
helping verb with past tense subject and
then the main verb and then in the noun
clause we have the subject and then the
verb as if it was a statement.
Should they write the email? Another yes
no question. We start with the
independent clause. He is not sure. Then
we start with if or whether
and then we have the subject they should
write the email.
So we're going to talk about one common
error that's uh a lot of people make a
mistake with using these types of noun
clauses.
The first error is using that and if or
whether to connect the independent
clause with the noun clause. So for
example, we have the student wants to
know that if there is homework.
So we can't use both that and if in the
sentence
to correct this error, we start with
this error. The student wants to know
that if there's homework, we just take
out that.
And now we have a sentence, complex
sentence with a if, weather, noun
clause.
